content: Is the STU3 Fhir-net-api library backward compatible to work with DSTU2 FHIR servers and applications?
no. Even the java one isn't, though the java one includes a conversion library between the two

Hi @Ramachandran G, FHIR STU3 has introduced breaking changes with respect to DSTU2, so the API releases for DSTU2 and STU3 are not compatible.
However we try to keep the public API interfaces of the DSTU2 and STU3 library versions to be the same as much as possible.

Hi, does anyone here know how you would code the following extension using fhir net api?

<extension url="http://hl7.org/fhir/us/core/StructureDefinition/us-core-race">
<extension url="ombCategory">
<valueCoding>
<system value="urn:oid:2.16.840.1.113883.6.238"/>
<code value="1000-9"/>
<display value="White"/>
</valueCoding>
</extension>
<extension url="text">
<valueString value="White"/>
</extension>
<extension url="detailed">
<valueCoding>
<system value="urn:oid:2.16.840.1.113883.6.238"/>
<code value="2108-9"/>
<display value="White European"/>
</valueCoding>
a</extension>
</extension>

new Hl7.Fhir.Model.Extension
            {
                Url = "http://hl7.org/fhir/us/core/StructureDefinition/us-core-race",
                Extension = new List<Hl7.Fhir.Model.Extension>
                {
                    new Hl7.Fhir.Model.Extension( "ombCategory", new Hl7.Fhir.Model.Coding( "urn:oid:2.16.840.1.113883.6.238", "1000-9", "White" ) ),
                    new Hl7.Fhir.Model.Extension( "text", new Hl7.Fhir.Model.FhirString( "White" ) ),
                    new Hl7.Fhir.Model.Extension( "detailed", new Hl7.Fhir.Model.Coding( "urn:oid:2.16.840.1.113883.6.238", "2108-9", "White-European" ) )
                }
            };
that seems an Argonaut race (http://fhir.org/guides/argonaut/StructureDefinition/argo-race) though, not the US core one
This is great though, I think from here I can get it into the correct format.
The US Core race extension is simpler - just a straight CodeableConcept
The US Core extensions in STU3 are the same as argonaut...i.e. more complex... based on the us regulations....
